document.docTitle: 3-Pentanol glycosides from root nodules of the actinorhizal plant Alnus cremastogyne

paragraph.docTitle:
3-Pentanol glycosides from root nodules of the actinorhizal plant
Alnus cremastogyne

document.paragraph:
Yingting Xu a, b, 1 , Yingchao Xu a, b, e, 1 , Zhengwan Huang a, b, 1 , Yucai Luo a, b , Ruanling Gao a , Jinghua Xue a, f , Changli Lin d , Katharina Pawlowski c , Zhongyu Zhou
a, f, *
, Xiaoyi Wei a, f

Key Laboratory of South China Agricultural Plant Molecular Analysis and Genetic Improvement
&

China Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Guangzhou, 510650, China

document.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

subSection.paragraph: Root nodules
3-Pentanol glycosides 3-Pentanol
A B S T R A C T

Alnus cremastogyne Burkill (Betulaceae)
, an actinorhizal plant, can enter a mutualistic symbiosis with
Frankia species
that leads to the formation of nitrogen fixing root nodules. Some primary metabolites (carbohydrates, dicarboxylic acids, amino acids, citrulline and amides) involved in carbon and nitrogen metabolism in actinorhizal nodules have been identified, while specialized metabolites in
A. cremastogyne
root nodules are yet to be characterized. In this study, we isolated and identified three undescribed 3-pentanol glycosides, i.e., 3-pentyl α -L- arabinofuranosyl-(1 ′′ →6 ′ )- β -D- glucopyranoside, 3-pentyl α -L- rhamnopyranosyl-(1 ′′ →6 ′ )- β -D- glucopyranoside, and 3-pentyl 6 ′ -(3-hydroxy3-methylglutaryl)- β -D- glucopyranoside, as well as seventeen known compounds from
A. cremastogyne
root nodules. 3-Pentanol glycosides are abundantly distributed in root nodules, while they are distributed in stems, roots, leaves and fruits at low/zero levels.
A. cremastogyne plants
treated by root nodule suspension emit 3-pentanol. This study enriches the knowledge about specialized metabolites in the actinorhizal host, and provides preliminarily information on the signal exchange in the actinorhizal symbiosis between
A. cremastogyne
and
Frankia
.

Alnus cremastogyne Burkill (Betulaceae)
, an actinorhizal plant, can enter a mutualistic symbiosis with
Frankia
. In infected cells of root nodules of
Alnus species
,
Frankia species
forms spherical vesicles, which act as the site for nitrogen fixation ( Swensen and Benson, 2008 ). While many studies have identified chemical components in members of the
Alnus
genus, phytochemical investigations of
A. cremastogyne
are rare. In addition to diarylheptanoids ( Ibrahim et al., 2016 ; Ilic-Tomic et al., 2017 ; Saxena et al., 2016 ; Sung and Lee, 2015 ), which are characteristic of the
Alnus
genus, triterpenoids ( Novakovic et al., 2017 ), flavonoids ( Ab Ghani et al., 2017 ), phenolic compounds ( Kim et al., 2016 ), shikimic acid ( Altinyay et al., 2016 ), sterols (Chen, C . K. et al., 2006; Knights et al., 1981 ), and xanthones ( Khvorost et al., 1987 ) have been identified in
Alnus species.
Previous phytochemical analyses of
Alnus species
covered various organs, including leaves ( Altinyay et al., 2016 ; Kim et al., 2016 ; Saxena et al., 2016 ), fruits ( Sung and Lee, 2015 ), stems (Chen, C . K. et al., 2006), flowers ( Ab Ghani et al., 2016 , 2017 ), and bark ( Ibrahim et al., 2016 ; Ilic-Tomic et al., 2017 ; Krasilnikova et al., 2018 ; Li, H. X. et al., 2015; Novakovic et al., 2017 ). Klika and colleagues isolated a compound, demethyl (C-11) cezomycin, from cultures of
Frankia sp.
AiPs1, which was isolated from
A. incana
plants ( Klika et al., 2001 , 2003). Hopanoid lipids, including bacteriohopanetetrol and bacteriohopanetetrol phenylacetate monoester, composed membrane of vesicles, which are specific cells, differentiated by
Frankia
to fix nitrogen ( Berry et al., 1991 , 1993 ). Sitosterol was found to be produced in nodules of three
Alnus species
( Knights et al., 1981 ).

* Corresponding author. Key Laboratory of South China Agricultural Plant Molecular Analysis and Genetic Improvement & Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Applied Botany, South China Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Guangzhou, 510650, China .
E-mail address: zhouzhongyu@scbg.ac.cn (Z. Zhou).
1 These authors contributed equally.

caption.paragraph: 1 H NMR Data of compounds 1–5 in CD OD at 500 MHz.

subSection.paragraph:
Twenty compounds, including three undescribed 3-pentanol glycosides (2–4) ( Fig. 1 ) and seventeen known compounds (1 and 5–20), were isolated and elucidated from root nodules of
A. cremastogyne
( Fig. S1 ).

Compound 2, obtained as a colourless oil, was found to have the molecular formula C 16 H 30 O 10 from pseudo-molecular ions at m/z 405 [M+Na] + in positive electrospray ionization-mass spectrometry (ESI-MS), m/z 417 [M+Cl] and 381 [M H] in negative ESI-MS, and m/z 405.1733 [M+Na] + in high-resolution (HR)-ESI-MS (calcd. for C 16 H 30 O 10 Na + : 405.1737). The 13 C nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrum ( Table 2 ) displayed 16 carbons, including two anomeric carbons ( δ 103.4 and 109.8) indicating the presence of two monosaccharides and a group of signals ( δ 10.1, 9.7, 28.0, 27.0, and 83.2) indicating the ether linkage with 3-pentanol, which was similar to compound 1. One distinct difference was that the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of compound 2 showed an additional monosaccharide. After detailed comparison with literature values, the additional monosaccharide was identified as arabinose. The glycosidic linkage between C-1 ′′ of arabinose and C-6 ′ of glucose was assigned according to the heteronuclear multiple bond correlations (HMBCs) from H-6 ′ ( δ 3.62 and 4.01) of glucose to C-1 ′′ ( δ 109.8) of arabinose ( Fig. 2 ). Additionally, the HMBC from H-1 ′ ( δ 4.33) to C-3 ( δ 83.2) of 3-pentanol supported the glycosidic linkages of glucose and 3-pentanol. α -Arabinose was confirmed on the basis of the anomeric proton doublet at δ H 5.00, with a small 3 J H-1,H-2 coupling constant (1.3 Hz). Similarly, β -glucose was identified based on the observation of an anomeric proton doublet at δ H 4.33 with a large 3 J H-1,H-2 coupling constant (7.7 Hz). Furthermore, acid hydrolysis ( Xiao et al., 2016 ) of compound 2 released D- glucose ( tR = 20.2 min) and L- arabinose ( tR = 22.4 min), which were detected after derivatisation by comparison of their retention time ( tR ) with derivatively authentic D- glucose ( tR = 20.3 min) and L- glucose ( tR = 18.7 min) and with derivatively authentic D- arabinose ( tR = 23.3 min) and L- arabinose ( tR = 22.5 min) in high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis ( Fig. S2 ), respectively. Therefore, compound 2 was identified as 3-pentyl α -L- arabinofuranosyl-(1 ′′ →6 ′ )- β -D -glucopyranoside.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. Chemical structures of four 3-pentanol glycosides (1–4) isolated from
A. cremastogyne
root nodules. They are 3-pentyl β -D- glucopyranoside (1), 3-pentyl α -L- arabinofuranosyl-(1 ′′ →6 ′ )- β - -glucopyranoside (2), 3-pentyl α - -rhamnopyranosyl-(1 ′′ →6 ′ )- β - -glucopyranoside (3), and 3-pentyl 6 ′ -(3-hydroxy3-methylglutaryl)- DLDβ -D- glucopyranoside (4).
13 C NMR Data of compounds 1–5 in CD OD at 125 MHz.

subSection.paragraph:
Compound 3, obtained as a colourless oil, had the molecular formula of C 17 H 32 O 10 based on pseudo-molecular ions at m/z 419 [M+Na] + in positive ESI-MS and m/z 395 [M H] in negative ESI-MS. After structure determination of 1 and 2, it was found that the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra ( Tables 1 and 2 ) of compound 3 displayed a group of signals ( δ 10.2, 9.8, 28.2, 27.3 and 83.3) indicating the presence of 3-pentanol as well as two anomeric carbons ( δ 103.7 and 102.2) and a secondary methyl ( δ H 1.01 and δ
C
18.0) indicating the presence of glucose and rhamnose. The ether linkage between 3-pentanol and glucose was the same as that in compounds 1 and 2. The glycosidic linkage between C-1 ′′ of rhamnose and C-6 ′ of glucose was assigned according to the HMBCs from H-6 ′ ( δ 3.59 and 3.96) of glucose to C-1 ′′ ( δ 102.2) of rhamnose ( Fig. 2 ). α -Rhamnose and β -glucose were confirmed on the basis of an anomeric proton doublet at δ H 4.75 with a small 3 J H-1,H-2 coupling constant (1.5 Hz) and an anomeric proton doublet at δ H 4.29 with a large 3 J H-1,H-2 coupling constant (7.8 Hz), respectively. Furthermore, acid hydrolysis ( Xiao et al., 2016 ) of compound 3 released D- glucose ( tR = 20.1 min) and L- rhamnose ( tR = 22.0 min), which were detected after derivatisation by comparison of their retention time ( tR ) with derivatively authentic D- glucose ( tR =20.3 min) and L- glucose ( tR =18.7 min) and with derivatively authentic L- rhamnose ( tR = 22.2 min) in HPLC analysis ( Fig. S2 ), respectively. Finally, compound 3 was identified as 3-pentyl α -L- rhamnopyranosyl-(1 ′′ →6 ′ )- β -D- glucopyranoside.

Compound 4, obtained as a colourless oil, was assigned the molecular formula of C 17 H 30 O 10 by positive HR-ESI-MS ( m/z [M+Na] + 417.1738, calcd. for C 17 H 30 O 10 Na + : 417.1737). The 13 C NMR spectrum ( Table 2 ) displayed 17 carbons, including one anomeric carbon ( δ 103.4) indicating the presence of one monosaccharide and a group of signals ( δ 10.1, 9.8, 28.0, 27.1 and 83.2) indicating the ether linkage with 3- pentanol, as well as two carbonyl carbons ( δ 172.4 and 174.9). Detailed NMR analysis of compound 4 led to the observation of 3-pentanol, glucose, and 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutarate groups, which was similar to compounds 1 and 5. Further analyses showed that compound 4 was a structural combination of compounds 1 and 5. The ester linkage between C-1 ′′ of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutarate (5) and C-6 ′ of glucose was determined according to the HMBCs from H-6 ′ ( δ 4.05 and 4.30) of glucose to C-1 ′′ ( δ 172.4) of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutarate (5) ( Fig. 2 ). Considering that acid hydrolysis of co-occurred compounds 1–3 released D- glucose, glucose in compound 4 was proposed to have the same D- configuration as those in compounds 1–3. Consequently, compound 4 was identified as 3-pentyl 6 ′ -(3-hydroxy3-methylglutaryl)- β -D- glucopyranoside.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Key heteronuclear multiple bond correlations of compounds 2–4.

Fig. 3. The contents of 3-pentanol. (A) The contents of free 3-pentanol. (B) The contents of 3-pentanol released from glycosides in various organs of
A. cremastogyne .
Values are in mean ± SD. Each n = 3 biological replicates.

heading.emphasis: 2.3. A. cremastogyne plants treated by root nodule suspension emit 3- pentanol

subSection.paragraph:
The
Frankia
microsymbiont from
A. cremastogyne
root nodules could not be isolated. Therefore, root nodule suspension (RNS) containing
Frankia
was used for infection. The emission of volatile organic chemicals (VOCs) by
A. cremastogyne plants
in response to infection was detected through solid phase micro-extraction (SPME) GC-MS. 3-Pentanol was detected both in VOCs released by
A. cremastogyne plants
treated with root nodule suspension (RNS) and by control RNS, while it was not detected in the VOCs released by control
A. cremastogyne
( Fig. 4A ). The emitted amounts of 3-pentanol in the VOCs released by
A. cremastogyne
treated with RNS increased from 0 to 12 h, whereas 3-pentanol emissions decreased in the VOCs released by control RNS during the same time period. This result indicated that the 3-pentanol in RNS-treated
A. cremastogyne
was formed by the plants, not by the bacteria in the RNS. The accumulated 3-pentanol in leaves and roots of
A. cremastogyne
was quantified after exposure to RNS for 12 h. 3-Pentanol was detected in both leaves and roots of
A. cremastogyne
treated with RNS, while it was not detected in either leaves or roots of control plants ( Fig. 4B ). The accumulated amounts of 3-pentanol in RNS-treated leaves and roots of
A. cremastogyne
were 172.7 nmol/g (FW) and 134.4 nmol/g (FW), respectively ( Fig. 4C ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 4.
A. cremastogyne plants
treated with root nodule suspension (RNS) emit 3-pentanol. (A) 3-Pentanol was detected in the VOCs of
A. cremastogyne
treated with RNS. The unity of Y-axis would be nmol per plant per h, and nmol per g nodules per h for groups of control
A. cremastogyne
and control RNS, respectively. n =5 (
A. cremastogyne
treated with RNS), 4 (control RNS), and 3 (control
A. cremastogyne
) biological replicates. The data shown are mean ± SD. Significant differences of
A. cremastogyne
treated with RNS from control RNS and from control
A. cremastogyne
are shown in * and # , respectively (Student’ s t -test: * and # indicate P < 0.05, while *** and ### indicate P < 0.001). (B) 3-Pentanol was detected in the body of
A. cremastogyne
treated with RNS ( n = 5 biological replicates). (C) The accumulated amounts of 3-pentanol in the leaves and roots of
A. cremastogyne
treated with RNS. The data shown are mean ± SD from three biological replicates.

subSection.paragraph:
RNS induces the accumulation and emission of 3-pentanol in
A. cremastogyne
. It was reported that 3-pentanol primes plant immunity in
Arabidopsis ( Song et al., 2015 )
, cucumber ( Song and Ryu, 2013 ) and pepper ( Choi et al., 2014 ), and is present as an attractant in volatile emissions from the ambrosia beetle
Megaplatypus mutatus ( Gatti Liguori et al., 2008 )
. It was tempting to speculate that 3-pentanol plays a role as a signaling molecule in the infection process between
Frankia
and
A. cremastogyne
. It is interesting to look at all the expressed genes in response to 3-pentanol by a global transcriptomic approach (RNA-seq), and to verify specific expressed genes by reverse transcription – quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) for further study.

In summary, three undescribed 3-pentanol glycosides, i.e., 3-pentyl α -L- arabinofuranosyl-(1 ′′ →6 ′ )- β -D- glucopyranoside (2), 3-pentyl α -L- rhamnopyranosyl-(1 ′′ →6 ′ )- β -D- glucopyranoside (3), and 3-pentyl 6 ′ -(3- hydroxy3-methylglutaryl)- β -D- glucopyranoside (4), together with seventeen known compounds (1 and 5–20), were isolated from
A. cremastogyne
root nodules. 3-Pentanol glycosides are abundantly distributed in
A. cremastogyne
root nodules, and they were discovered in natural occurrence for the first time.
A. cremastogyne plants
treated by root nodule suspension emit 3-pentanol. This study enriches specialized metabolites knowledge about actinorhizal symbiont, and provides preliminarily chemical understanding in actinorhizal symbiosis between
Frankia
and
A. cremastogyne
.

1 H and 13 C NMR spectra were recorded in CD 3 OD on a Bruker DRX-500 NMR (Bruker Biospin Gmbh, Rheinstetten, Germany ) instrument using the residual solvent peak as reference, spectrometers operating at 500 MHz for 1 H and 125 MHz for 13 C NMR, respectively. The spectral widths were set at 10,000 Hz for 1 H NMR, and 29,762 Hz for 13 C NMR. The relaxation delays were set to 1.0 s for 1 H NMR, and 2.0 s for 13 C NMR. Electrospray ionization mass spectra (ESI-MS) were collected on an API 2000 LC/MS/MS instrument (Applied Biosystems Inc., Forster ¨, CA, USA ). High resolution (HR) ESI-MS were acquired on an ACQUITY UPLC I-Class/Xevo G2-XS QTOF. Column chromatography (CC) was performed on silica gel (80–100 mesh, and 200–300 mesh, Yantai Jiangyou Silica Gel Development Co., Ltd., Yantai, China ), and on Sephadex LH-20 (Pharmacia Fine Chemicals Co., Ltd., Uppsala , Sweden ). TLC was conducted on precoated silica gel plates (HSGF254, Yantai Jiangyou Silica Gel Development Co., Ltd., Yantai, China ) and spot detection was performed by spraying with 5% vanillin aldehyde sulfuric acid, followed by heating. Analytical grade ethyl acetate and methanol were purchased from Tianjin Baishi Chemical Co., Ltd. ( Tianjin , China ). Acetone and chloroform were purchased from Guangzhou Guang Test Agent Technology Co., Ltd. (Guangzhou, China ), petroleum ether (bp 60–90 ◦ C ) was purchased from Tianjin Yongda Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. ( Tianjin , China ).

heading.emphasis: 4.2. Plant growth conditions and A. cremastogyne materials

subSection.paragraph:
For extraction and isolation,
Alnus cremastogyne Burkill (Betulaceae)
root nodules ( 127 g DW ) were collected from at least three trees in January 2018 from Yunhe County in Zhejiang Province , China (GPS- Coordinates:
28 ◦ 5 ′ 21.79 ′′ N
,
119 ◦ 31 ′ 10.62 ′′ E
). A voucher specimen (zzy20180117) was deposited at the Laboratory of Phytochemistry at the South China Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences. For root nodule suspension ( RNS ) preparation, root nodules were freshly collected from the same site. For acid hydrolysis and GC-MS analysis,
A. cremastogyne
leaves, stems, fruits, root nodules, and roots were collected from plants containing nodules in October 2018 from Yunhe County in Zhejiang Province , China . Samples were ground in liquid nitrogen and stored at 80 ◦ C .

A. cremastogyne
seeds were collected from Yunhe County in Zhejiang Province , China . The seeds were scarified and sterilized with 95% ethanol for 30 s and 5% sodium hypochlorite for 10 min, and washed with sterile water for four times, and then sowed in pots with sterilized horticultural soil containing vermiculite (3:1). They were grown in a greenhouse for 10 weeks (16 h light/8 h dark cycle). The growing
A. cremastogyne
seedlings are shown in Fig. S4A.

Air-dried root nodules ( 127 g DW) were ground and extracted four times with CHCl 3 – CH 3 OH (1:1, v/v) at r. t. to give a crude extract, which was subjected to reverse-phase C 18 medium-pressure liquid chromatography, silica gel and Sephadex LH-20 column chromatography for isolation. A flow chart depicting the phytochemical extraction and isolation of compounds 1–20 in detail is shown in Fig. S5.

3-Pentyl α -L- arabinofuranosyl-(1 ′′ →6 ′ )- β -D- glucopyranoside (2). Colourless oil; 1 H and 13 C NMR, see Tables 1 and 2 , respectively; HRESIMS (positive) m/z 405.1733 [M+Na] + (calcd. for C 16 H 30 O 10 Na + , 405.1737).

3-Pentyl α -L- rhamnopyranosyl-(1 ′′ →6 ′ )- β -D- glucopyranoside (3). Colourless oil; 1 H and 13 C NMR, see Tables 1 and 2 , respectively; ESIMS (negative) m/z 395 [M H], ESIMS (positive) m/z 419 [M+Na] + , C 17 H 32 O 10 .

3-Pentyl 6 ′ -(3-hydroxy3-methylglutaryl)- β -D- glucopyranoside (4). Colourless oil; 1 H and 13 C NMR, see Tables 1 and 2 , respectively; HRESIMS (positive) m/z [M+Na] + 417.1738 (calcd. for C 17 H 30 O 10 Na + , 417.1737).

Acid hydrolysis was conducted following the procedures described by Xiao et al. (2016) . Compounds 1–3 (each 1 mg ) were dissolved in 5 mL of 2 M aqueous hydrochloride and refluxed at 100 ◦ C for 4 h. After removal of the solution under vacuum, 5 mL distilled water was added and then partitioned with 5 mL ethyl acetate three times. The aqueous layer was condensed to dryness, and the residue was dissolved in 1 mL pyridine containing 1 mg /mL L-cysteine methyl ester hydrochloride. After the solution was heated at 60 ◦ C for 1 h, O -tolylisothiocyanate (2 mL) was added, and the solution was maintained at 60 ◦ C for an additional 1 h and then condensed to dryness under vacuum. The residue was dissolved in 1 mL MeOH and analysed by HPLC with two Shimadzu LC-20AT pumps, a Shimadzu SPD-M20 A diode array detector, and a Shimadzu SIL-20 A auto sampler using an Agilent Zorbax SB-Aq column (5 μm, 4.6 × 250 mm ); acetonitrile ( CH 3 CN)/H 2 O/acetic acid (22:78:0.1) was used as the mobile phase at a flow rate of 1 mL/min for 60 min, and the column was then washed with 90% aqueous CH 3 CN. D- Glucose, L- arabinose, and L- rhamnose in the acid hydrolysates were detected by comparison of their tR values with those of authentic D- glucose ( tR =20.3 min), L- glucose ( tR = 18.7 min), D- arabinose ( tR = 23.3 min), L- arabinose ( tR =22.5 min), and L- rhamnose ( tR =22.2 min), which were hydrolysed by acid using the same procedures.

emphasis.heading: 4.5. Acid hydrolysis and GC-MS analysis of different A. cremastogyne
organs

subSection.paragraph:
Different
A. cremastogyne organs
, including leaves, stems, fruits, root nodules, and roots were analysed with three biological replicates. About fifty milligrams of powder from each sample was transferred to a well capped flask containing 2 mL of 1 M H 2 SO 4 (Fig. S6) as group of acid hydrolysis, or containing 2 mL of ultrapure water as group of without acid hydrolysis. The samples were refluxed at 100 ◦ C for 4 h. Subsequently, 100 μL of the headspace in each flask was immediately submitted to GC-MS (QP2010 Plus; Shimadzu, Tokyo , Japan ) analysis equipped with a GC column (SUPELCOWAX-10, 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm, Supelco Inc., Bellefonte, PA, USA ). The oven temperature was maintained for 1 min at 40 ◦ C , increased to 115 ◦ C at a rate of 3 ◦ C /min, increased to 240 ◦ C at a rate of 40 ◦ C /min, and held for 10 min. The injector temperature was 250 ◦ C , and the ion source temperature was 230 ◦ C . Helium was used as the carrier gas at a 1.0 mL/min flow rate. 3- Pentanol was identified by comparing with the authentic 3-pentanol standard (Item No. W330036; purchased from Saen Chemical TechnologyCo., LTD, Shanghai , China ). Quantification of 3-pentanol contents was performed based on a calibration curve.

This experiment included three treatments, i.e.
A. cremastogyne
treated with root nodule suspension ( RNS ), control RNS , control
A. cremastogyne
treated with BAP medium containing nitrogen sources ( Murry et al., 1984 ). 12-Week-old un-inoculated
A. cremastogyne
seedlings were freshly collected and roots were mildly washed to remove soil for subsequent RNS and BAP treatments. RNS was prepared using 0.6 g fresh, clean and crushed root nodules in 40 mL BAP medium for per
A. cremastogyne
seedling treatment. The root system of a whole seedling was immersed in 40 mL RNS or BAP medium. SPME (Catalog no. 57328-U, Supelco, Bellefonte, PA, USA ) was used to sample VOCs from
A. cremastogyne
for 30 min at each time point (0 h, 6 h and 12 h) in the headspaces of 2 L beakers ( Fig. S4B ). After exposure to each treatment for 12 h, the whole seedlings were washed to remove the RNS or BAP medium. Then, the roots and leaves of
A. cremastogyne
were finely ground in liquid nitrogen, respectively. 300 mg (fresh weight) roots or leaf powder was extracted using 1.8 mL of dichloromethane and 5 nmol of ethyl n -decanoate (internal standard) was added. The extraction was performed at room temperature overnight on a shaker. The resulting solution was obtained, and dried over anhydrous Na 2 SO4. Both the SPME fibers containing VOCs and 1 μL of the dichloromethane extracts were subjected to GC-MS analysis. The GC-MS conditions were the same with part 4.5.

The numbers of biological replicate of each experiment are given in the corresponding figure legends. Statistical significance was tested as described in the figure legends. All statistical analyses were performed in Excel.

This research was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant number 31970376), CAS, China President’ s International Fellowship Initiative (2023VBA0010), Youth Innovation Promotion Association CAS, China to Zhongyu Zhou (grant number 2016310), Guangdong Special Support Program (grant number 2015TQ01R054), and Guangzhou Science and Technology Program (grant number 201904010134).
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
Data will be made available on request.

We thank Mr. Yunfei Yuan, South China Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences for NMR spectroscopic measurements; Ms. Yongxia Jia, Yangyang Xiao and Qiuxia Yang, South China Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences for GC-MS analysis; Dr. Long Wang, South China Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences for
Alnus cremastogyne
plant identification.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2022.113582.
